segment.target: Getting started: Animation

segment.source: Getting started: Animation
segment.target: Getting started: Animation

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Adding animations
segment.target: Adding animations

segment.source: In iOS, you most often create animation effects programmatically.
segment.target: In iOS, you most often create animation effects programmatically.

segment.source: For example, you might use animations provided by the block-based UIView class's animateWithDuration methods, or the older non-block based methods.
segment.target: For example, you might use animations provided by the block-based UIView class's animateWithDuration methods, or the older non-block based methods.

segment.source: Or, you might explicitly use the CALayer class to animate layers.
segment.target: Or, you might explicitly use the CALayer class to animate layers.

segment.source: Animations in Windows apps can be created programmatically, but they can also be defined declaratively with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).
segment.target: Animations in Windows apps can be created programmatically, but they can also be defined declaratively with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).

segment.source: You can use Microsoft Visual Studio to edit XAML code directly, but Visual Studio also comes with a tool called Blend, which creates XAML code for you as you work with animations in a designer.
segment.target: You can use Microsoft Visual Studio to edit XAML code directly, but Visual Studio also comes with a tool called Blend, which creates XAML code for you as you work with animations in a designer.

segment.source: In fact, Blend allows you to open, design, build, and run complete Visual Studio projects, graphically.
segment.target: In fact, Blend allows you to open, design, build, and run complete Visual Studio projects, graphically.

segment.source: The following walkthrough lets you try this out.
segment.target: The following walkthrough lets you try this out.

segment.source: Create a new Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app and name it something like "SimpleAnimation".
segment.target: Create a new Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app and name it something like "SimpleAnimation".

segment.source: In this project, we're going to move a rectangle, apply a fade effect, and then bring it back into view.
segment.target: In this project, we're going to move a rectangle, apply a fade effect, and then bring it back into view.

segment.source: Animations in XAML are based on the concept of storyboards (not to be confused with iOS storyboards).
segment.target: Animations in XAML are based on the concept of storyboards (not to be confused with iOS storyboards).

segment.source: Storyboards use keyframes to animate property changes.
segment.target: Storyboards use keyframes to animate property changes.

segment.source: With your project open, in Solution Explorer, right-click the project's name and then select Open in Blend or Design in Blend, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: With your project open, in Solution Explorer, right-click the project's name and then select Open in Blend or Design in Blend, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: Visual Studio continues to run in the background.
segment.target: Visual Studio continues to run in the background.

segment.source: open in blend menu command
segment.target: open in blend menu command

segment.source: After Blend starts, you should see something similar to the following figure.
segment.target: After Blend starts, you should see something similar to the following figure.

segment.source: blend development environment
segment.target: blend development environment

segment.source: Double-click on MainPage.xaml in the Solution Explorer on the left hand side.
segment.target: Double-click on MainPage.xaml in the Solution Explorer on the left hand side.

segment.source: Next, from the vertical strip of tools on the edge of the central Design View, select the Rectangle tool, and then draw a rectangle in Design View, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: Next, from the vertical strip of tools on the edge of the central Design View, select the Rectangle tool, and then draw a rectangle in Design View, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: adding a rectangle to design view
segment.target: adding a rectangle to design view

segment.source: To make the rectangle green, look in the Properties window, and in the Brush area, click on the Solid color brush button, and then click the Color eyedropper icon.
segment.target: To make the rectangle green, look in the Properties window, and in the Brush area, click on the Solid color brush button, and then click the Color eyedropper icon.

segment.source: Click somewhere in the green band of hues.
segment.target: Click somewhere in the green band of hues.

segment.source: To begin animating the rectangle, in the Objects and Timeline window, tap the plus symbol (New) button as shown in the following figure, and then tap OK.
segment.target: To begin animating the rectangle, in the Objects and Timeline window, tap the plus symbol (New) button as shown in the following figure, and then tap OK.

segment.source: adding a storyboard
segment.target: adding a storyboard

segment.source: A storyboard appears in the Objects and Timeline window (you may need to resize the view to see it properly).
segment.target: A storyboard appears in the Objects and Timeline window (you may need to resize the view to see it properly).

segment.source: The Design View display changes to show that Storyboard1 timeline recording is on.
segment.target: The Design View display changes to show that Storyboard1 timeline recording is on.

segment.source: To capture the current state of the rectangle, in the Objects and Timeline window, tap the Record Keyframe button just above the yellow arrow, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: To capture the current state of the rectangle, in the Objects and Timeline window, tap the Record Keyframe button just above the yellow arrow, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: recording a keyframe
segment.target: recording a keyframe

segment.source: Now, let's move the rectangle and fade it away.
segment.target: Now, let's move the rectangle and fade it away.

segment.source: To do this, drag the orange/yellow arrow to the 2-second position, and then move your green rectangle slightly to the right.
segment.target: To do this, drag the orange/yellow arrow to the 2-second position, and then move your green rectangle slightly to the right.

segment.source: Then, in the Properties window, in the Appearance area, change the Opacity property to 0, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: Then, in the Properties window, in the Appearance area, change the Opacity property to 0, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: To preview the animation, tap the Play button in the Storyboard panel.
segment.target: To preview the animation, tap the Play button in the Storyboard panel.

segment.source: properties windows and play button
segment.target: properties windows and play button

segment.source: Next, let's bring the rectangle back into view.
segment.target: Next, let's bring the rectangle back into view.

segment.source: In the Objects and Timeline window, double-click Storyboard1.
segment.target: In the Objects and Timeline window, double-click Storyboard1.

segment.source: Then, in the Properties window, in the Common area, select AutoReverse, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: Then, in the Properties window, in the Common area, select AutoReverse, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: selecting a storyboard
segment.target: selecting a storyboard

segment.source: Finally, click on the Play button to see what happens.
segment.target: Finally, click on the Play button to see what happens.

segment.source: You can build and run the project by clicking on the green run button at the top of the window (or just press F5).
segment.target: You can build and run the project by clicking on the green run button at the top of the window (or just press F5).

segment.source: If you do this, you'll see your project will indeed build and run, but the green rectangle will stubbornly sit perfectly still, like a toddler denied candy in a supermarket aisle.
segment.target: If you do this, you'll see your project will indeed build and run, but the green rectangle will stubbornly sit perfectly still, like a toddler denied candy in a supermarket aisle.

segment.source: To start the animation, you'll need to add a line of code to the project.
segment.target: To start the animation, you'll need to add a line of code to the project.

segment.source: Here's how.
segment.target: Here's how.

segment.source: Save the project, by opening the File menu, and selecting Save MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: Save the project, by opening the File menu, and selecting Save MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: Return to Visual Studio.
segment.target: Return to Visual Studio.

segment.source: If Visual Studio displays a dialog box asking whether you want to reload the modified file, select Yes.
segment.target: If Visual Studio displays a dialog box asking whether you want to reload the modified file, select Yes.

segment.source: Double-click the MainPage.xaml.cs file, which is hidden under MainPage.xaml, to open it, and add the following code just above the public MainPage() method:
segment.target: Double-click the MainPage.xaml.cs file, which is hidden under MainPage.xaml, to open it, and add the following code just above the public MainPage() method:

segment.source: Run the project again, and watch the rectangle animate.
segment.target: Run the project again, and watch the rectangle animate.

segment.source: Hurrah!
segment.target: Hurrah!

segment.source: If you open the MainPage.xaml file, in XAML view, you'll see the XAML code that Blend added for you as you worked in the designer.
segment.target: If you open the MainPage.xaml file, in XAML view, you'll see the XAML code that Blend added for you as you worked in the designer.

segment.source: In particular, look at the code in the and elements.
segment.target: In particular, look at the code in the and elements.

segment.source: The following code shows an example.
segment.target: The following code shows an example.

segment.source: Ellipses indicate unrelated code omitted for brevity, and line breaks have been added for code readability.)
segment.target: Ellipses indicate unrelated code omitted for brevity, and line breaks have been added for code readability.)

segment.source: You can edit this XAML manually, or return to Blend to continue working on it there.
segment.target: You can edit this XAML manually, or return to Blend to continue working on it there.

segment.source: Blend makes it fun to create interesting user interfaces, and the ability to animate them using a graphical tool can dramatically speed up development time.
segment.target: Blend makes it fun to create interesting user interfaces, and the ability to animate them using a graphical tool can dramatically speed up development time.

segment.source: For more info about animations, see Animations overview.
segment.target: For more info about animations, see Animations overview.

segment.source: Note For info about animations for Windows Store apps using JavaScript and HTML, see Animating your UI (HTML).
segment.target: Note For info about animations for Windows Store apps using JavaScript and HTML, see Animating your UI (HTML).
